text: From: Paul, called to be an apostle of the Messiah Jesus by the will of God, and from our brother Sosthenes.
speaker: Narrator

text: To: God’s church in Corinth, to those who have been sanctified by the Messiah Jesus and called to be holy, together with all those everywhere who call on the name of our Lord Jesus, the Messiah—their Lord and ours.
speaker: Narrator

text: May grace and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus, the Messiah, be yours!
speaker: Narrator

text: I always thank my God for you because of the grace of God given you by the Messiah Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by him you have become rich in every way—in speech and knowledge of every kind—
speaker: Narrator

text: while our testimony about the Messiah has been confirmed among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, you don’t lack any spiritual gift as you eagerly wait for our Lord Jesus the Messiah to be revealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will keep you strong until the end, so that you will be blameless on the Day of our Lord Jesus the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Faithful is the God by whom you were called into fellowship with his Son Jesus the Messiah, our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, in the name of our Lord Jesus the Messiah, I urge all of you to be in agreement and not to have divisions among you, so that you may be perfectly united in your understanding and opinions.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, some members of Chloe’s family have made it clear to me that there are quarrels among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what I mean: Each of you is saying, “I belong to Paul,” or “I belong to Apollos,” or “I belong to Cephas,” or “I belong to the Messiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Is the Messiah divided? Paul wasn’t crucified for you, was he? You weren’t baptized in Paul’s name, were you?
speaker: Narrator

text: I thank God that I did not baptize any of you except Crispus and Gaius,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that no one can say that you were baptized in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Oh yes, I also baptized the family of Stephanas. Beyond that, I’m not sure whether I baptized anyone else.)
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Messiah did not send me to baptize but to preach the gospel, not with eloquent wisdom, so the cross of the Messiah won’t be emptied of its power.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the message about the cross is nonsense to those who are being destroyed, but it is God’s power to us who are being saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is written,
“I will destroy the wisdom of the wise,
    and the intelligence of the intelligent I will reject.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is the wise person? Where is the scholar? Where is the philosopher of this age? God has turned the wisdom of the world into nonsense, hasn’t he?
speaker: Narrator

text: For since, in the wisdom of God, the world through its wisdom did not know God, God was pleased to save those who believe through the nonsense of our preaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jews ask for signs, and Greeks look for wisdom,
speaker: Narrator

text: but we preach the Messiah crucified. He is a stumbling block to Jews and nonsense to gentiles,
speaker: Narrator

text: but to those who are called, both Jews and Greeks, the Messiah is God’s power and God’s wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God’s nonsense is wiser than human wisdom, and God’s weakness is stronger than human strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, think about your own calling. Not many of you were wise by human standards, not many were powerful, not many were of noble birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God chose what is nonsense in the world to make the wise feel ashamed. God chose what is weak in the world to make the strong feel ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God chose what is insignificant in the world, what is despised, what is nothing, in order to destroy what is something,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that no one may boast in God’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is because of God that you are in union with the Messiah Jesus, who for us has become wisdom from God, as well as our righteousness, sanctification, and redemption.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, as it is written, “The person who boasts must boast in the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I came to you, brothers, I didn’t come and tell you about God’s secret with rhetorical language or wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For while I was with you I resolved to know nothing except Jesus the Messiah, and him crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was in weakness, fear, and great trembling that I came to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: My message and my preaching were not accompanied by clever, wise words, but by a display of the Spirit’s power,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that your faith would not be based on human wisdom but on God’s power.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, when we are among mature people, we do speak a message of wisdom, but not the wisdom of this world or of the rulers of this world, who are passing off the scene.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, we speak about God’s wisdom in a hidden secret, which God destined before the world began for our glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: None of the rulers of this world understood it, because if they had, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as it is written,
“No eye has seen, no ear has heard,
    and no mind has imagined
the things that God has prepared
    for those who love him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God has revealed those things to us by his Spirit. For the Spirit searches everything, even the deep things of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is there anyone who can understand his own thoughts except his own inner spirit? In the same way, no one can know the thoughts of God except God’s Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, we have not received the spirit of the world but the Spirit who comes from God, so that we can understand the things that were freely given to us by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: We don’t speak about these things with words taught us by human wisdom, but with words taught by the Spirit, as we explain spiritual things to spiritual people.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person who isn’t spiritual doesn’t accept the things of God’s Spirit, for they are nonsense to him. He can’t understand them because they are spiritually evaluated.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spiritual person evaluates everything but is subject to no one else’s evaluation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For
“Who has known the mind of the Lord
    so that he can advise him?”
However, we have the mind of the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, I couldn’t talk to you as spiritual people but as worldly people, as mere infants in the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave you milk to drink, not solid food, because you weren’t ready for it. And you’re still not ready!
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s because you are still worldly. As long as there is jealousy and quarreling among you, you are worldly and living by human standards, aren’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: For when one person says, “I follow Paul,” and another person says, “I follow Apollos,” you’re following your own human nature, aren’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is Apollos, anyhow? Or who is Paul? They’re merely servants through whom you came to believe, as the Lord gave to each of us his task.
speaker: Narrator

text: I planted, Apollos watered, but God kept everything growing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So neither the one who plants nor the one who waters is significant, but God, who keeps everything growing, is the one who matters.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who plants and the one who waters have the same goal, and each will receive a reward for his own action.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are God’s co-workers. You are God’s farmland and God’s building.
speaker: Narrator

text: As an expert builder using the grace that God gave me, I laid the foundation, and someone else is building on it. But each person must be careful how he builds on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, no one can lay any other foundation than the one that is already laid, and that is Jesus the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether a person builds on this foundation with gold, silver, expensive stones, wood, hay, or straw,
speaker: Narrator

text: the workmanship of each person will become evident, for the day of judgment will show what it is, because it will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test the quality of each person’s action.
speaker: Narrator

text: If what a person has built on the foundation survives, he will receive a reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his work is burned up, he will suffer loss. However, he himself will be saved, but it will be like going through fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that you are God’s sanctuary and that God’s Spirit lives in you, don’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone destroys God’s sanctuary, God will destroy him, for God’s sanctuary is holy. And you are that sanctuary!
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one deceive himself. If any of you thinks he is wise in the ways of this world, he must become a fool to become really wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the wisdom of this world is nonsense in God’s sight. For it is written,
“He catches the wise with their own trickery,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
and again,
“The Lord knows that the thoughts of the wise are worthless.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So let no one boast about human beings, since everything belongs to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: whether Paul, Apollos, Cephas, the world, life, death, the present, or the future—everything belongs to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you belong to the Messiah, and the Messiah belongs to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Think of us as servants of the Messiah and as servant managers entrusted with God’s secrets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it is required of servant managers that each one should prove to be trustworthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a very small thing to me that I should be examined by you or by any human court. In fact, I don’t even evaluate myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my conscience is clear, but that does not vindicate me. It is the Lord who examines me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, stop judging prematurely, before the Lord comes, for he will bring to light what is now hidden in darkness and reveal the motives of our hearts. Then each person will receive his praise from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, I have applied all this to Apollos and myself for your benefit, so that you may learn from us not to go beyond what the Scriptures say. Then you will stop boasting about one person at the expense of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who makes you superior? What do you have that you did not receive? And if you did receive it, why do you boast as though you did not receive it?
speaker: Narrator

text: You already have all you want! You have already become rich! You have become kings without us! I wish you really were kings so that we could be kings with you!
speaker: Narrator

text: For it seems to me that God has put us apostles on display in last place, like men condemned to death. We have become a spectacle for the world, for angels, and for people to stare at.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are fools for the Messiah’s sake, but you are wise in the Messiah. We are weak, but you are strong. You are honored, but we are dishonored.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are hungry, thirsty, dressed in rags, brutally treated, and homeless, right up to the present.
speaker: Narrator

text: We wear ourselves out from working with our own hands. When insulted, we bless. When persecuted, we endure.
speaker: Narrator

text: When slandered, we answer with kind words. Even now we have become the filth of the world, the scum of the universe.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m not writing this to make you feel ashamed, but to warn you as my dear children.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may have 10,000 mentors who work for the Messiah, but not many fathers. For in the Messiah Jesus I became your father through the gospel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I urge you to imitate me.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why I sent Timothy to you. He is my dear and dependable son in the Lord and will help you remember how I live for the Messiah Jesus as I teach everywhere in every church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of you have become arrogant, as though I were not coming to evaluate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will come to you soon if it’s the Lord’s will. Then I’ll discover not only what these arrogant people are saying but also what power they have,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the kingdom of God isn’t just talk, but also power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Which do you prefer? Should I come to you with a stick, or with love and a gentle spirit?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is actually reported that sexual immorality exists among you, and of a kind that is not found even among the gentiles. A man is actually living with his father’s wife!
speaker: Narrator

text: And you are being arrogant instead of being filled with grief and seeing to it that the man who did this is removed from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though I am away from you physically, I am with you in spirit. I have already passed judgment on the man who did this, as though I were present with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the name of our Lord Jesus, when you are gathered together (and I am there in spirit), and the power of our Lord Jesus is there, too,
speaker: Narrator

text: turn this man over to Satan for the destruction of his body, so that his spirit may be saved on the Day of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your boasting is not good. You know that a little yeast leavens the whole batch of dough, don’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Get rid of the old yeast so that you may be a new batch of dough, since you are to be free from yeast. For the Messiah, our Passover, has been sacrificed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So let’s keep celebrating the festival, neither with old yeast nor with yeast that is evil and wicked, but with yeast-free bread that is both sincere and true.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wrote to you in my letter to stop associating with people who are sexually immoral—
speaker: Narrator

text: not at all meaning the people of this world who are immoral, greedy, robbers, or idolaters. In that case you would have to leave this world.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now I am writing to you to stop associating with any so-called brother if he is sexually immoral, greedy, an idolater, a slanderer, a drunk, or a robber. You must even stop eating with someone like that.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, is it my business to judge outsiders? You are to judge those who are in the community, aren’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: God will judge outsiders. “Expel that wicked man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of you has a complaint against another, does he dare to take the matter before those who are unrighteous and not before the saints?
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that the saints will rule the world, don’t you? And if the world is going to be ruled by you, can’t you handle insignificant cases?
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that we will rule angels, not to mention things in this life, don’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you have cases dealing with this life, why do you appoint as judges people who have no standing in the church?
speaker: Narrator

text: I say this to make you feel ashamed. Has it come to this, that there is not one person among you who is wise enough to settle disagreements between brothers?
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, one brother goes to court against another brother, and before unbelieving judges, at that!
speaker: Narrator

text: The very fact that you have lawsuits among yourselves is already a defeat for you. Why not rather just accept the wrong? Why not rather be cheated?
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you yourselves practice doing wrong and cheating others, and brothers at that!
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that wicked people will not inherit the kingdom of God, don’t you? Stop deceiving yourselves! Sexually immoral people, idolaters, adulterers, male prostitutes, homosexuals,
speaker: Narrator

text: thieves, greedy people, drunks, slanderers, and robbers will not inherit the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is what some of you were! But you were washed, you were sanctified, you were justified in the name of our Lord Jesus the Messiah and by the Spirit of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything is permissible for me, but not everything is helpful. Everything is permissible for me, but I will not allow anything to control me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Food is for the stomach, and the stomach is for food, but God will make them both unnecessary. The body is not meant for sexual immorality but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: God raised the Lord, and by his power he will also raise us.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that your bodies belong to the Messiah, don’t you? Should I take what belongs to the Messiah and unite them with a prostitute? Certainly not!
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that the person who unites himself with a prostitute becomes one body with her, don’t you? For it is said, “The two will become one flesh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who unites himself with the Lord becomes one spirit with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep on running away from sexual immorality. Any other sin that a person commits is outside his body, but the person who sins sexually sins against his own body.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that your body is a sanctuary of the Holy Spirit who is in you, whom you have received from God, don’t you? You do not belong to yourselves,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you were bought for a price. Therefore, glorify God with your bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now about what you asked: “Is it advisable for a man not to touch a woman inappropriately?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, and yet because sexual immorality is so rampant, every man should have his own wife, and every woman should have her own husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: A husband should fulfill his obligation to his wife, and a wife should do the same for her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wife does not have authority over her own body, but her husband does. In the same way, a husband doesn’t have authority over his own body, but his wife does.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not withhold yourselves from each other unless you agree to do so just for a set time, in order to devote yourselves to prayer. Then you should come together again so that Satan does not tempt you through your lack of self-control.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I say this as a concession, not as a command.
speaker: Narrator

text: I would like everyone to be unmarried, like I am. However, each person has a special gift from God, one this and another that.
speaker: Narrator

text: I say to those who are unmarried, especially to widows: It is good for them to remain like me.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if they cannot control themselves, they should get married, for it is better to marry than to burn with passion.
speaker: Narrator

text: To married people I give this command (not really I, but the Lord): A wife must not leave her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if she does leave him, she must remain unmarried or else be reconciled to her husband. Likewise, a husband must not abandon his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: I (not the Lord) say to the rest of you: If a brother has a wife who is an unbeliever and she is willing to live with him, he must not abandon her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if a woman has a husband who is an unbeliever and he is willing to live with her, she must not abandon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the unbelieving husband has been sanctified because of his wife, and the unbelieving wife has been sanctified because of her husband. Otherwise, your children would be unclean, but now they are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the unbelieving partner leaves, let him go. In such cases the brother or sister is not under obligation. God has called you to live in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wife, you might be able to save your husband. Husband, you might be able to save your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, everyone should live the life that the Lord gave him and to which God called him. This is my rule in all the churches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was anyone circumcised when he was called? He should not try to change that. Was anyone uncircumcised when he was called? He should not get circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing, but obeying God’s commandments is everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone should stay in the same condition in which he was called.
speaker: Narrator

text: Were you a slave when you were called? Do not let that bother you. Of course, if you have a chance to become free, take advantage of the opportunity.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the slave who has been called to belong to the Lord is the Lord’s free person. In the same way, the free person who has been called is the Messiah’s slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were bought for a price. Stop becoming slaves of people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, everyone should stay in the same condition in which he was called by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning virgins, although I do not have any command from the Lord, I will give you my opinion as one who by the Lord’s mercy is trustworthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: In view of the present crisis, I think it is prudent for a man to stay as he is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you become committed to a wife? Stop trying to get released from your commitment. Have you been freed from your commitment to a wife? Stop looking for one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do get married, you have not sinned. And if a virgin gets married, she has not sinned. However, these people will experience trouble in this life, and I want to spare you from that.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what I mean, brothers: The time is short. From now on, those who have wives should live as though they had none,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those who mourn as though they did not mourn, and those who rejoice as though they were not rejoicing, and those who buy as though they did not own a thing,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those who use the things in the world as though they were not dependent on them. For the world in its present form is passing away.
speaker: Narrator

text: I want you to be free from concerns. An unmarried man is concerned about the things of the Lord, that is, about how he can please the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a married man is concerned about things of this world, that is, about how he can please his wife,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and so his attention is divided.
An unmarried woman or virgin is concerned about the affairs of the Lord, so that she may be holy in body and spirit. But a married woman is concerned about the affairs of this world, that is, about how she can please her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m saying this for your benefit, not to put a noose around your necks, but to promote good order and unhindered devotion to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man thinks he is not behaving properly toward his virgin, and if his passion is so strong that he feels he ought to marry her, let him do what he wants; he isn’t sinning. Let them get married.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if a man stands firm in his resolve, feels no necessity, and has made up his mind to keep her a virgin, he will be acting appropriately.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then the man who marries the virgin acts appropriately, but the man who refrains from marriage does even better.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives. But if her husband dies, she is free to marry anyone she wishes, only in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, in my opinion she will be happier if she stays as she is. And in saying this, I think that I, too, have God’s Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning food offered to idols: We know that we all possess knowledge. Knowledge puffs up, but love builds up.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone thinks he really knows something, he has not yet learned it as he ought to know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone who loves God is known by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning eating food offered to idols: We know that no idol is real in this world and that there is only one God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For even if there are “gods” in heaven and on earth (as indeed there are many so-called “gods” and “lords”),
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet for us
there is only one God, the Father,
    from whom everything came into being
        and for whom we live.
And there is only one Lord, Jesus the Messiah,
    through whom everything came into being
        and through whom we live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But not everyone has this knowledge. Some people are so accustomed to idolatry that when they eat food that has been offered to an idol, their conscience becomes contaminated because it is weak.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, food will not bring us closer to God. We are no worse off if we do not eat food that has been offered to an idol, and no better off if we do.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must see to it that this right of yours does not become a stumbling block for those who are weak.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if anyone with a weak conscience sees you, who know better, eating in an idol’s temple, he will be encouraged to eat what has been offered to idols, won’t he?
speaker: Narrator

text: In that case, the weak brother for whom the Messiah died is ruined by your knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you sin against your brothers in this way and wound their weak consciences, you are sinning against the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, if food that I eat causes my brother to stumble, I will never eat meat again, in order to keep my brother from stumbling.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am free, am I not? I am an apostle, am I not? I have seen Jesus our Lord, haven’t I? You are the result of my work in the Lord, aren’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I am not an apostle to other people, surely I am one to you, for you are the evidence of my apostolic authority from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is my defense to those who would examine me:
speaker: Narrator

text: We have the right to earn our food, don’t we?
speaker: Narrator

text: We have the right to take a believing wife with us like the other apostles, the Lord’s brothers, and Cephas, don’t we?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or is it only Barnabas and I who have to keep on working for a living?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who ever goes to war at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat any of its grapes? Or who takes care of a flock and does not drink any of its milk?
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not saying this on human authority, am I? The Law says the same thing, doesn’t it?
speaker: Narrator

text: For in the Law of Moses it is written, “You must not muzzle an ox while it is treading out the grain.” God is not only concerned about oxen, is he?
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t he really speaking for our benefit? Yes, this was written for our benefit, because the one who plows should plow in hope, and the one who threshes should thresh in hope of sharing in the crop.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we have sown spiritual seed among you, is it too much if we reap material benefits from you?
speaker: Narrator

text: If others enjoy this right over you, don’t we have a stronger claim? But we did not use this right. On the contrary, we tolerate everything in order not to put an obstacle in the way of the gospel of the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that those who work in the Temple get their food from the Temple and that those who serve at the altar get their share of its offerings, don’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, the Lord has ordered that those who proclaim the gospel should make their living from the gospel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have not used any of these rights, and I’m not writing this so that they may be applied in my case. I would rather die than let anyone deprive me of my reason for boasting.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I preach the gospel, I have nothing to boast about, for this obligation has been entrusted to me. How terrible it would be for me if I didn’t preach the gospel!
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I preach voluntarily, I get a reward, but if I am unwilling to do it, I am still entrusted with that obligation.
speaker: Narrator

text: What, then, is my reward? It is to be able to preach the gospel free of charge, and so I never resort to demanding my rights when I’m preaching the gospel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although I am free from everyone’s expectations, I have made myself a servant to all of them to win more people.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Jews I became like a Jew in order to win Jews. To those under the Law I became like a man under the Law, in order to win those under the Law (although I myself am not under the Law).
speaker: Narrator

text: To those who do not have the Law, I became like a man who does not have the Law in order to win those who do not have the Law. However, I am not free from God’s Law, but I’m subject to the Messiah’s law.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the weak I became weak in order to win the weak. I have become all things to all people so that by all possible means I might save some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do all this for the sake of the gospel in order to have a share in its blessings.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that in a race all the runners run but only one wins the prize, don’t you? You must run in such a way that you may be victorious.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who enters an athletic contest practices self-control in everything. They do it to win a wreath that withers away, but we run to win a prize that never fades.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is the way I run, with a clear goal in mind. That is the way I fight, not like someone shadow boxing.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, I keep on disciplining my body, making it serve me so that after I have preached to others, I myself will not somehow be disqualified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I do not want you to be ignorant, brothers, of the fact that all of our ancestors who left Egypt were under the cloud. They all went through the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they all were immersed into Moses in the cloud and in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all ate the same spiritual food
speaker: Narrator

text: and drank the same spiritual drink, for they drank from the spiritual rock that went with them. That rock was the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God wasn’t pleased with most of those people, and so they were struck down in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now their experiences serve as examples for us so that we won’t set our hearts on evil as they did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s stop being idolaters, as some of them were. As it is written, “The people sat down to eat and drink and got up to play.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s stop sinning sexually, as some of them were doing, and on a single day 23,000 fell dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s stop putting the Lord to the test, as some of them were doing, and were destroyed by snakes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must stop complaining, as some of them were doing, and were annihilated by the destroyer.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things happened to them to serve as an example, and they were written down as a warning for us in whom the culmination of the ages has been attained.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, whoever thinks he is standing securely should watch out so he doesn’t fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: No temptation has overtaken you that is unusual for human beings. But God is faithful, and he will not allow you to be tempted beyond your strength. Instead, along with the temptation he will also provide a way out, so that you may be able to endure it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so, my dear friends, keep on running away from idolatry.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am talking to sensible people. Apply what I am saying to yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cup of blessing that we bless is our fellowship in the blood of the Messiah, isn’t it? The bread that we break is our fellowship in the body of the Messiah, isn’t it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Because there is one loaf, we who are many are one body, because all of us eat from the same loaf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at the Israelis from a human point of view. Those who eat the sacrifices share in what is on the altar, don’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I suggesting that an offering made to idols means anything, or that an idol itself means anything?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hardly! What they offer, they offer to demons and not to God, and I do not want you to become partners with demons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You cannot drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons. You cannot dine with the Lord and dine with demons,
speaker: Narrator

text: or you’ll provoke the Lord to jealousy, won’t you? Are we stronger than he is?
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything is permissible, but not everything is helpful. Everything is permissible, but not everything builds up.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one should seek his own welfare, but rather his neighbor’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat anything that is sold in the meat market without raising any question about it on the grounds of conscience,
speaker: Narrator

text: for “the earth and everything in it belong to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If an unbeliever invites you to his house and you wish to go, eat whatever is set before you, raising no question on the grounds of conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if someone says to you, “This was offered as a sacrifice,” don’t eat it, both out of consideration for the one who told you and also for the sake of conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: I mean, of course, his conscience, not yours. For why should my freedom be determined by someone else’s conscience?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I eat with thankfulness, why should I be denounced because of what I am thankful for?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, whether you eat or drink, or whatever you do, do everything for the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t become a stumbling block to Jews or Greeks or to the church of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as I myself try to please everybody in every way. I don’t look out for my own benefit, but rather for the benefit of many people, so that they might be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Imitate me, as I do the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: I praise you for remembering everything I told you and for holding to the traditions that I passed on to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I want you to realize that the Messiah is the head of every man, and man is the head of the woman, and God is the head of the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man who prays or prophesies with something on his head dishonors his head,
speaker: Narrator

text: and every woman who prays or prophesies with her head uncovered dishonors her head, which is the same as having her head shaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if a woman does not cover her head, she should cut off her hair. If it is a disgrace for a woman to cut off her hair or shave her head, let her cover her own head.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man should not cover his head, because he exists as God’s image and glory. But the woman is man’s glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: For man did not come from woman, but woman from man;
speaker: Narrator

text: and man was not created for woman, but woman for man.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is why a woman should have authority over her own head: because of the angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the Lord, however, woman is not independent of man, nor is man of woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as woman came from man, so man comes through woman. But everything comes from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Decide for yourselves: Is it proper for a woman to pray to God with her head uncovered?
speaker: Narrator

text: Nature itself teaches you neither that it is disgraceful for a man to have long hair
speaker: Narrator

text: nor that hair is a woman’s glory, since hair is given as a substitute for coverings.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone wants to argue about this, we do not have any custom like this, nor do any of God’s churches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I am not praising you in giving you the following instructions. When you gather, it is not for the better but for the worse.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in the first place, I hear that when you gather as a church there are divisions among you, and I partly believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of course, there must be factions among you to show which of you are genuine!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you gather in the same place, it is not to eat the Lord’s Supper.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as you eat, each of you rushes to eat his own supper, and one person goes hungry while another gets drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have homes in which to eat and drink, don’t you? Or do you despise God’s church and humiliate those who have nothing? What should I say to you? Should I praise you? I will not praise you for this!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I received from the Lord what I also passed on to you—how the Lord Jesus, on the night he was betrayed, took a loaf of bread,
speaker: Narrator

text: gave thanks for it, and broke it in pieces, saying, “This is my body that is for you. Keep doing this in memory of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He did the same with the cup after the supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in my blood. As often as you drink from it, keep doing this in memory of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For as often as you eat this bread and drink from this cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death until he comes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, whoever eats the bread or drinks from the cup in an unworthy manner will be held responsible for the Lord’s body and blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person must examine himself and then eat the bread and drink from the cup,
speaker: Narrator

text: because whoever eats and drinks without recognizing the body, eats and drinks judgment on himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s why so many of you are weak and sick and a considerable number are dying.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we judged ourselves correctly, we would not be judged.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, while we are being judged by the Lord, we are being disciplined so we won’t be condemned along with the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, my brothers, when you gather to eat, wait for each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone is hungry, he should eat at home, so that when you gather it may not bring judgment on you. And when I come I will give instructions concerning the other matters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning spiritual gifts, brothers, I don’t want you to be ignorant.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that when you were unbelievers, you were enticed and led astray to worship idols that couldn’t even speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason I want you to be aware that no one who is speaking by God’s Spirit can say, “Jesus is cursed,” and no one can say, “Jesus is Lord,” except by the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there are varieties of gifts, but the same Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: and there are varieties of ministries, but the same Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are varieties of results, but it is the same God who produces all the results in everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: To each person has been given the ability to manifest the Spirit for the common good.
speaker: Narrator

text: To one has been given a message of wisdom by the Spirit; to another the ability to speak with knowledge according to the same Spirit;
speaker: Narrator

text: to another faith by the same Spirit; to another gifts of healing by that one Spirit;
speaker: Narrator

text: to another miraculous results; to another prophecy; to another the ability to distinguish between spirits; to another various kinds of languages; and to another the interpretation of languages.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one and the same Spirit produces all these results and gives what he wants to each person.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the body is one and yet has many parts, and all the parts of the body, though many, form a single body, so it is with the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by one Spirit all of us—Jews and Greeks, slaves and free—were baptized into one body and were all privileged to drink from one Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the body does not consist of only one part, but of many.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the foot says, “Since I’m not a hand, I’m not part of the body,” that does not make it any less a part of the body, does it?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if the ear says, “Since I’m not an eye, I’m not part of the body,” that does not make it any less a part of the body, does it?
speaker: Narrator

text: If the whole body were an eye, where would the sense of hearing be? If the whole body were an ear, where would the sense of smell be?
speaker: Narrator

text: But now God has arranged the parts, every one of them, in the body according to his plan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if all of it were one part, there wouldn’t be a body, would there?
speaker: Narrator

text: So there are many parts, but one body.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye cannot say to the hand, “I don’t need you,” or the head to the feet, “I don’t need you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the contrary, those parts of the body that seem to be weaker are in fact indispensable,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the parts of the body that we think are less honorable are treated with special honor, and we make our less attractive parts more attractive.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, our attractive parts don’t need this. But God has put the body together and has given special honor to the parts that lack it,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that there might be no disharmony in the body, but that its parts should have the same concern for each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one part suffers, every part suffers with it. If one part is praised, every part rejoices with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are the Messiah’s body and individual parts of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has appointed in the church first of all apostles, second prophets, third teachers, then those who perform miracles, those who have gifts of healing, those who help others, administrators, and those who speak various kinds of languages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not all are apostles, are they? Not all are prophets, are they? Not all are teachers, are they? Not all perform miracles, do they?
speaker: Narrator

text: Not all have the gift of healing, do they? Not all speak in foreign languages, do they? Not all interpret, do they?
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep on desiring the better gifts. And now I will show you the best way of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I speak in the languages of humans and angels but have no love, I have become a reverberating gong or a clashing cymbal.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have the gift of prophecy and can understand all secrets and every form of knowledge, and if I have absolute faith so as to move mountains but have no love, I am nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if I give away everything that I have and sacrifice myself, but have no love, I gain nothing.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: Love never fails. Now if there are prophecies, they will be done away with. If there are languages, they will cease. If there is knowledge, it will be done away with.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what we know is incomplete and what we prophesy is incomplete.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when what is complete comes, then what is incomplete will be done away with.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, thought like a child, and reasoned like a child. When I became a man, I gave up my childish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we see only an indistinct image in a mirror, but then we will be face to face. Now what I know is incomplete, but then I will know fully, even as I have been fully known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right now three things remain: faith, hope, and love. But the greatest of these is love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep on pursuing love, and keep on desiring spiritual gifts, especially the ability to prophesy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the person who speaks in a foreign language is not actually speaking to people but to God. Indeed, no one understands him, because he is talking about secrets by the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who prophesies speaks to people for their upbuilding, encouragement, and comfort.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who speaks in a foreign language builds himself up, but the person who prophesies builds up the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I wish that all of you could speak in foreign languages, but especially that you could prophesy. The person who prophesies is more important than the person who speaks in a foreign language, unless he interprets it so that the church may be built up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, brothers, if I come to you speaking in foreign languages, what good will I be to you unless I speak to you in some revelation, knowledge, prophecy, or teaching?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, lifeless instruments like the flute or harp produce sounds. But if there’s no difference in the notes, how can a person tell what tune is being played?
speaker: Narrator

text: For example, if a bugle doesn’t sound a clear call, who will get ready for battle?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, unless you speak an intelligible message with your language, how will anyone know what is being said? You’ll be talking into the air!
speaker: Narrator

text: There are, I suppose, many different languages in the world, yet none of them is without meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I don’t know the meaning of the language, I will be a foreigner to the speaker and the speaker will be a foreigner to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, since you’re so desirous of spiritual gifts, you must keep on desiring them for building up the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, the person who speaks in a foreign language should pray for the ability to interpret it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I pray in a foreign language, my spirit prays but my mind is not productive.
speaker: Narrator

text: What does this mean? I will pray with my spirit, but I will also pray with my mind. I will sing psalms with my spirit, but I will also sing psalms with my mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, if you say a blessing with your spirit, how can an otherwise uneducated person say “Amen” to your thanksgiving, since he does not know what you’re saying?
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s good for you to give thanks, but it does not build up the other person.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thank God that I speak in foreign languages more than all of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in church I would rather speak five words with my mind to instruct others than 10,000 words in a foreign language.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, stop being childish in your thinking. Be like infants with respect to evil, but think like adults.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the Law it is written,
“By means of foreign languages
    and through the mouths of foreigners
I will speak to this people,
    but even then they will not listen to me,”
        declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foreign languages, then, are meant to be a sign, not for believers, but for unbelievers, while prophecy is meant, not for unbelievers, but for believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if the whole church gathers in the same place and everyone is speaking in foreign languages, when uneducated people or unbelievers come in, they will say that you are out of your mind, won’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if everyone is prophesying, when an unbeliever or an uneducated person comes in he will be convicted and examined by everything that’s happening.
speaker: Narrator

text: His secret, inner heart will become known, and so he will bow down to the ground and worship God, declaring, “God is truly among you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: What, then, does this mean, brothers? When you gather, everyone has a psalm, teaching, revelation, foreign language, or interpretation. Everything must be done for upbuilding.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone speaks in a foreign language, only two or three at the most should do so, one at a time, and somebody must interpret.
speaker: Narrator

text: If an interpreter is not present, the speaker should remain silent in the church and speak to himself and God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two or three prophets should speak, and others should weigh carefully what is said.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a revelation is made to another person who is seated, the first person should be silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: For everyone can prophesy in turn, so that everyone can be instructed and everyone can be encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spirits of prophets are subject to the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for God is not a God of disorder but of peace.
As in all the churches of the saints,
speaker: Narrator

text: the women must keep silent in the churches. They are not allowed to speak out, but must place themselves in submission, as the oral law also says.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they want to learn anything, they should ask their own husbands at home, for it is inappropriate for a woman to speak out in church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Did God’s word originate with you? Are you the only ones it has reached?
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone thinks he is a prophet or a spiritual person, he must acknowledge that what I am writing to you is the Lord’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone ignores this, he should be ignored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, my brothers, desire the ability to prophesy, and do not prevent others from speaking in foreign languages.
speaker: Narrator

text: But everything must be done in a proper and orderly way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I’m making known to you, brothers, the gospel that I proclaimed to you, which you accepted, on which you have taken your stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and by which you are also being saved if you hold firmly to the message I proclaimed to you—unless, of course, your faith was worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I passed on to you the most important points that I received: The Messiah died for our sins according to the Scriptures,
speaker: Narrator

text: he was buried, he was raised on the third day according to the Scriptures—and is still alive!—
speaker: Narrator

text: and he was seen by Cephas, and then by the Twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, he was seen by more than 500 brothers at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next he was seen by James, then by all the apostles,
speaker: Narrator

text: and finally he was seen by me, as though I were born abnormally late.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am the least of the apostles and not even fit to be called an apostle because I persecuted God’s church.
speaker: Narrator

text: But by God’s grace I am what I am, and his grace shown to me was not wasted. Instead, I worked harder than all the others—not I, of course, but God’s grace that was with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, whether it was I or the others, this is what we preach, and this is what you believed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if we preach that the Messiah has been raised from the dead, how can some of you keep claiming there is no resurrection of the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is no resurrection of the dead, then the Messiah has not been raised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if the Messiah has not been raised, then our message means nothing and your faith means nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, we are found to be false witnesses about God because we testified on God’s behalf that he raised the Messiah—whom he did not raise if in fact it is true that the dead are not raised.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the dead are not raised, then the Messiah has not been raised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if the Messiah has not been raised, your faith is worthless and you are still imprisoned by your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, even those who have died believing in the Messiah are lost.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we have set our hopes on the Messiah in this life only, we deserve more pity than any other people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But at this moment the Messiah stands risen from the dead, the first one offered in the harvest of those who have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: For since death came through a man, the resurrection of the dead also came through a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as in Adam all die, so also in the Messiah will all be made alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, this will happen to each person in the proper order: first the Messiah, then those who belong to the Messiah when he comes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the end will come, when after he has done away with every ruler and every authority and power, the Messiah hands over the kingdom to God the Father.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he must rule until God puts all the Messiah’s enemies under his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The last enemy to be done away with is death,
speaker: Narrator

text: for “God has put everything under his feet.” Now when he says, “Everything has been put under him,” this clearly excludes the one who put everything under him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when everything has been put under him, then the Son himself will also become subject to the one who put everything under him, so that God may be all in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, what will those people do who are being baptized because of those who have died? If the dead are not raised at all, why are they being baptized because of them?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why in fact are we being endangered every hour?
speaker: Narrator

text: I face death every day! That is as certain, brothers, as it is that I am proud of you in the Messiah, Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have fought with wild animals in Ephesus from merely human motives, what do I get out of it? If the dead are not raised,
“Let’s eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stop being deceived:
“Wicked friends lead to evil ends.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Come back to your senses as you should, and stop sinning! For some of you—I say this to your shame—don’t fully know God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone will ask, “How are the dead raised? What kind of body will they have when they come back?”
speaker: Narrator

text: You fool! The seed you plant does not come to life unless it dies,
speaker: Narrator

text: and what you plant is not the form that it will be, but a bare kernel, whether it is wheat or something else.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God gives the plant the form he wants it to have, and to each kind of seed its own form.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not all flesh is the same. Humans have one kind of flesh, animals in general have another, birds have another, and fish have still another.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are heavenly bodies and earthly bodies, but the splendor of those in heaven is of one kind, and that of those on earth is of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: One kind of splendor belongs to the sun, another to the moon, and still another to the stars. In fact, one star differs from another star in splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how it will be at the resurrection of the dead. What is planted is decaying, what is raised cannot decay.
speaker: Narrator

text: The body is planted in a state of dishonor but is raised in a state of splendor. It is planted in weakness but is raised in power.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is planted a physical body but is raised a spiritual body. If there is a physical body, there is also a spiritual body.
speaker: Narrator

text: This, indeed, is what is written: “The first man, Adam, became a living being.” The last Adam became a life-giving spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spiritual does not come first, but the physical does, and then comes the spiritual.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first man came from the dust of the earth; the second man came from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are made of the dust are like the man from the dust; those who are heavenly are like the man who is from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as we have borne the likeness of the man who was made from dust, we will also bear the likeness of the man from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, this is what I mean: Mortal bodies cannot inherit the kingdom of God, and what decays cannot inherit what does not decay.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me tell you a secret. Not all of us will die, but all of us will be changed—
speaker: Narrator

text: in a moment, faster than an eye can blink, at the sound of the last trumpet. Indeed, that trumpet will sound, and then the dead will be raised never to decay, and we will be changed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what is decaying must be clothed with what cannot decay, and what is dying must be clothed with what cannot die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, when what is decaying is clothed with what cannot decay, and what is dying is clothed with what cannot die, then the written word will be fulfilled: “Death has been swallowed up by victory!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where, O death, is your victory?
    Where, O death, is your sting?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now death’s stinger is sin, and sin’s power is the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus the Messiah!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, my dear brothers, be steadfast, unmovable, always excelling in the work of the Lord, because you know that the work that you do for the Lord isn’t wasted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning the collection for the saints, you should follow the directions I gave to the churches in Galatia.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Sabbath ends, each of you should set aside and save something from your surplus in proportion to what you have, so that no collections will have to be made when I arrive.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I arrive, I will send letters along with the men you approve to take your gift to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is worthwhile for me to go, too, they can go with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will visit you when I go through Macedonia—for I intend to go through Macedonia—
speaker: Narrator

text: and will probably stay with you for a while or even spend the winter with you. Then you can send me on my way, wherever I decide to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not want to visit with you now just in passing, because I hope to spend a longer time with you if the Lord permits.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I’ll stay on in Ephesus until Pentecost,
speaker: Narrator

text: because a door has opened wide for me to do effective work, although many people are opposing me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Timothy comes, see to it that he does not have anything to be afraid of while he is with you, for he is doing the Lord’s work as I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, no one should treat him with contempt. Send him on his way in peace so that he may come to me, because I am expecting him along with the brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning our brother Apollos, I strongly urged him to visit you with the other brothers, but he was not inclined to do so just now. However, he will visit you when the time is right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remain alert. Keep standing firm in your faith. Keep on being courageous and strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything you do should be done lovingly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I urge you, brothers—for you know that the members of the family of Stephanas were the first converts in Achaia, and that they have devoted themselves to serving the saints—
speaker: Narrator

text: to submit yourselves to people like these and to anyone else who shares their labor and hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am glad that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus came here, because what was lacking they have supplied through you.
speaker: Narrator

text: They refreshed my spirit—and yours, too. Therefore, appreciate men like that.
speaker: Narrator

text: The churches in Asia greet you. Aquila and Prisca and the church in their house greet you warmly in union with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the brothers greet you. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Paul, am writing this greeting with my own hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If anyone doesn’t love the Lord,
    let him be anathema!
        Marana tha!
speaker: Narrator

text: May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May my love remain with all of you
    in union with the Messiah Jesus.
speaker: Narrator
